rules.natural: Provided that alcohol is approved for the platform, then the product becomes market available.
Either alcohol is approved for the platform or substance is approved for the platform.
A drug has emergency use authorization or it has conditional approval.
If a drug has conditional approval, then it does not require clinical trials.
When an application for alcohol is submitted, the outcome is either fast-track approval for the drug or, assuming therapeutic benefit, absence of addictive property in substance.
An application has been submitted for alcohol or one has been submitted for substance.
If the implication that emergency use authorization negates the need for clinical trials does not hold, then the drug faces regulatory investigation.
In the situation where emergency use authorization failing to waive clinical trials occurs, regulatory investigation does not follow.
Whenever the approval of substance for the platform does not lead to market availability, the drug requires clinical trials.
Provided that it is not the case that the drug is approved for research or exempt from clinical trials, then the drug is a banned substance.

If the failure of the implication that substance's application submission leads to fast-track approval or non-addictive therapeutic benefit does not result in application rejection, then an appeal is filed for substance.
Under the condition that the non-implication of substance's application submission to approval paths not causing rejection, an appeal is not filed for substance.
In the event the product is not market available, substance has an addictive property.

facts.natural: It is not the case that the application for substance is rejected.
A drug is not approved for research.
A drug is not a banned substance.
A drug does not qualify for fast-track approval.

steps.natural: Either a drug is approved for research or it does not require clinical trials.
A drug does not require clinical trials.
If substance is approved for the platform, then the product is market available.

Should it not be the case that submitting an application for substance implies either fast-track approval or therapeutic benefit without addictive property, then the application for substance is rejected.
Whenever an application for substance is submitted, either the drug qualifies for fast-track approval or, if the drug has therapeutic benefit, then substance lacks an addictive property.
The drug qualifies for fast-track approval, or, provided the drug has therapeutic benefit, substance has no addictive property.
In the event that a drug has therapeutic benefit, substance does not possess an addictive property.
Substance does not have an addictive property.
Under the condition that a drug has emergency use authorization, it does not require clinical trials.
A drug does not require clinical trials.
If substance is approved for the platform, then the product is market available.

natural_facts.A2: Substance has approval for the platform.
natural_facts.A4: A drug is approved for research.
natural_facts.A5: A drug is a banned substance.
natural_facts.A8: A drug qualifies for fast-track approval.
natural_facts.A9: An application for alcohol has been submitted.
natural_facts.A10: An application for substance has been submitted.
natural_facts.A11: The application for substance has been rejected.
natural_facts.A12: An appeal has been filed for substance.
natural_facts.A13: A drug has emergency use authorization.
natural_facts.A15: A drug is under regulatory investigation.

(A1 → G).natural: Provided that alcohol is approved for the platform, then the product becomes market available.

(A1 ∨ A2).natural: Either alcohol is approved for the platform or substance is approved for the platform.

(A10 → (A8 ∨ (A7 → ¬A6))).natural: Whenever an application for substance is submitted, either the drug qualifies for fast-track approval or, if the drug has therapeutic benefit, then substance lacks an addictive property.

(A13 → ¬A3).natural: Under the condition that a drug has emergency use authorization, it does not require clinical trials.

(A13 ∨ A14).natural: A drug has emergency use authorization or it has conditional approval.

(A14 → ¬A3).natural: If a drug has conditional approval, then it does not require clinical trials.

(A2 → G).natural: If substance is approved for the platform, then the product is market available.

(A4 ∨ ¬A3).natural: Either a drug is approved for research or it does not require clinical trials.

(A7 → ¬A6).natural: In the event that a drug has therapeutic benefit, substance does not possess an addictive property.

(A8 ∨ (A7 → ¬A6)).natural: The drug qualifies for fast-track approval, or, provided the drug has therapeutic benefit, substance has no addictive property.

(A9 → (A8 ∨ (A7 → ¬A6))).natural: When an application for alcohol is submitted, the outcome is either fast-track approval for the drug or, assuming therapeutic benefit, absence of addictive property in substance.

(A9 ∨ A10).natural: An application has been submitted for alcohol or one has been submitted for substance.

(¬(A10 → (A8 ∨ (A7 → ¬A6))) → A11).natural: Should it not be the case that submitting an application for substance implies either fast-track approval or therapeutic benefit without addictive property, then the application for substance is rejected.

(¬(A13 → ¬A3) → A15).natural: If the implication that emergency use authorization negates the need for clinical trials does not hold, then the drug faces regulatory investigation.

(¬(A13 → ¬A3) → ¬A15).natural: In the situation where emergency use authorization failing to waive clinical trials occurs, regulatory investigation does not follow.

(¬(A2 → G) → A3).natural: Whenever the approval of substance for the platform does not lead to market availability, the drug requires clinical trials.

(¬(A4 ∨ ¬A3) → A5).natural: Provided that it is not the case that the drug is approved for research or exempt from clinical trials, then the drug is a banned substance.

(¬(¬(A10 → (A8 ∨ (A7 → ¬A6))) → A11) → A.natural: If the failure of the implication that substance's application submission leads to fast-track approval or non-addictive therapeutic benefit does not result in application rejection, then an appeal is filed for substance.

(¬(¬(A10 → (A8 ∨ (A7 → ¬A6))) → A11) → ¬.natural: Under the condition that the non-implication of substance's application submission to approval paths not causing rejection, an appeal is not filed for substance.

(¬G → A6).natural: In the event the product is not market available, substance has an addictive property.

¬A11.natural: It is not the case that the application for substance is rejected.

¬A3.natural: A drug does not require clinical trials.

¬A4.natural: A drug is not approved for research.

¬A5.natural: A drug is not a banned substance.

¬A6.natural: Substance does not have an addictive property.

¬A8.natural: A drug does not qualify for fast-track approval.
